videos.title: Le r√©alisateur de "P√©pouze au coin du feu" - Karim Duval a.k.a Doug Wong
videos.description:
#feudechemin√©e #fireplace #cheminee 
Le r√©alisateur de la vid√© du feu de chemin√©e. Pas celle que vous pensez. L'autre.

Version originale (anglaise) de l'interview :

When the streaming platforms scrambled to buy the rights to "Chillin' by the fire-side", I realised just how far we'd come in the last twelve years. No-one believed in the project initially!
It may sound crazy now, but at the time, showing a fire burning in a fireplace on your TV screen wasn't exactly the most natural idea in the world !

August 2011. I walked into Jim Sanders' office (the boss of CWBBHYS). I remember it as if it was yesterday. There he was, tucking into a Quarter Pounder with cheese, with a large fries and an Extra Large Coke. And I said: "Jim, put that burger down, will you, and just listen to this". And I pitched him the idea for the film: "It's the story of a fire that's burning in a fireplace..." (well, nowadays, you know the rest...) And to my great disappointment, Jim just looked at me and goes:
"Dude, are you out of your mind? Just because we had a big hit with "The Niagara Falls"' doesn't mean that people are ready to stare at an open fire for hours on end!"

At the time, I was absolutely stunned by his reaction, as if I'd been hit by an uppercut from Tommy Hearns in '84, if you know what I mean... Because I was obsessed by this idea of a film that's halfway between the avant-garde cinema of Eric Rohmer and the Hollywood neo-classicism of Coppola!
It wasn't until years later that I realised that "Chillin' by the fire-side" was not actually meant to be an art-house film, but a genuine blockbuster! 

So, twelve years later, after getting caught up in music with my EP "Wind in the Cypress Leaves", I went back to see Jim Sanders. He was tucking into a Quarter Pounder with cheese, with a large Fries and an Extra Large Coke. I said "Jim, put that burger down, will you, and just listen to this!"
He goes: "Oh, me oh my, Doug! The last time you said that to me, I nearly lost a load of money!"
And I said: "But, that's just it. Do you remember my idea about a fire in the fireplace...?"
And he goes: "Quit with the bullshit, Doug!".
But I insist, I keep hammering away:
"You know, Jim, society has changed... People want to watch a roaring fire in their living room on a big TV screen, with scented candles and inspirational quotes hanging on the wall. Or even... with a Quarter Pounder with cheese, a Large Fries and an Extra Large Coke..."
(I could see Jim's eyes light up, so I didn't let up)
"You know, Jim, over these last 17 years, I've come to realise that this film tells my story. It's the story of an every-day American guy who dreamt of climbing up the social ladder, of being able to afford a house with a fireplace..."

And then Jim interrupts me and says:

"Careful now, Doug, you're slipping back into your pseudo-intellectual, arty-farty movie talk! Come on, in the pitch, you've gotta go big on the burger idea. We're not just going to make a film with your fireplace, we're going to make a whole series!"
And I said: "Are you serious? Now, you're losing it, big time!
He goes: 
"Write me a screenplay and a narrative arc. I'll look after ordering a pile of logs... and I'll even splash the cash!

And I go: "It's as good as done!"

And the next day, we were talking about filming angles. I had a wide-angle shot in mind, with a progressive slow-moving zoom. He goes: "Dude, don't do your head in. Just give me a good fixed shot and that'll be fine."
Today, I am grateful to the Lord for putting me on Jim's path, because now we're working on season 5. In 3D and virtual reality. It's absolutely incredible!
